about_the_game:
A concentrate of tactical decisions. No need to spend 30 minutes setting up in the beginning, or an hour at the end cleaning up the map. Get your strategy fix with satisfying 5-minute battles that focus on tactical decisions, not micromanagement or actions per minute.

Your personality and choices matter! Discover the unique, irreverent universe of the Killbots as you choose your own path in the dynamic branching storylines, where your choices as well as your successes affect the outcome.

Even bring one or two friends and forge the unique story of your alliance together!

Like pieces on a chess board, gameplay is accessible (and controller-friendly!) yet deep, involving light resource management, multiple unit types, strategic strikes and terrain evaluation. Speaking of which...

In Killbot General, the high ground (and other terrain features) matters. This means every procedural map presents a unique challenge for you to ponder and adapt to.

Fight for (and against!) any faction you wish to create! Create everything starting from the name, leader, what it's fighting for and its motto; even import your own PNG image and put what you want on the flag.

Bergviz the Maztocs

We've been told that no one reads all the way down in the store text. Is this true? Is anyone reading this? Am I talking to myself? Don't answer that. Actually, you probably have no idea how long it took to write every sentence in all our marketing material, writing and rewriting, to convey the best parts of the game. Yeah, I know; it's not Shakespeare, but we work so hard on the game we want to get it all perfect. I've got to say: if you've made it this far, I'm impressed! This is shaping up to be a big, unappealing "Wall of text". Not everyone would've actually dared give it a second look. On top of that, it's right above the system requirements! Yikes. Honestly, that's where *I* stop reading, and on a good day. Although below that, there is the "More like this" section, and often that's cool, so I skip right to it. That's all well and good, but I've actually got to finish all the other marketing things. Man, there's a lot. I think I might be dragging this out, just to avoid looking at the pile of marketing things. I'd rather be working on the game right now, but we've got to get this done as it's important. Anyway, thanks for checking out the game and getting this far! You should probably get a little something for going through all this. Tell you what; if you register for our newsletter by going to the special address berguevizthemaztocs [dot] universeworkshopstudios [dot] com, I'll make sure you get the earliest access to the playtests, and any other cool stuff we might do. It'll also be cool to know that someone actually read this. Actually, I've got to Google "Bergueviz the Maztocs" first, to check if it means something offensive in another language. Or if it's slang for something nasty or whatever. It's really just the first couple of random sounds that came to mind when I was trying to think of random sounds to write down for this thing, so who knows what I could've stumbled upon. Ok; I checked and looks like it's fine, so I'm ready to go here. Thanks again for checking out KG! We'll see you out there, friend.

name: Killbot General

pc_requirements.minimum:
Minimum:
  • OS: Windows 10 or newer
  • Processor: 2.5 GHz Dual core
  • Memory: 8 GB RAM
  • Graphics: NVIDIA GeForce 760, AMD Radeon R7 270X, or better
  • DirectX: Version 11
  • Storage: 300 MB available space
pc_requirements.recommended:
Recommended:
  • OS: Windows 10 or newer
  • Processor: 3.0+ GHz Quad core
  • Memory: 8 GB RAM
  • Graphics: NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1060, AMD Radeon RX 470, or better
  • DirectX: Version 11
  • Storage: 300 MB available space

short_description: Satisfying real-time tactics packed in 5-minute battles. Create a customized cause and lead it to glory as its hero Killbot General in the crazy and irreverent, dynamic (choices matter!) story campaign, in solo or co-op. Controller-friendly, with emphasis on tactics, not speed or micromanagement.
